course.subject: MATH
course.name: Fundamentals of Actuarial Mathematics
course.description: This course covers the fundamental concepts of actuarial financial mathematics and how these concepts are applied in calculating present and accumulated values for various streams of cash flows. The topics covered include interest rates, present value, annuities valuation, loan repayment, bond and portfolio yield, bond valuation, rate of return, yield curve, term structure of interest rates, duration and convexity of general cash flows and portfolios, immunization, stock valuation, capital budgeting, dynamic cash flow processes, and asset and liability management.
course.prerequisites: MATH 1003 OR MATH 1014 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024

reviews.author: calcguy
reviews.title: An "Introductory" Financial Mathematics Course, but with TEDIOUS EXAMS
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 : Basic Interest Theory [A prerequisite for remaining chapters]
* Amount function and Accumulation Function
* Simple Interest, Compounded Interest and Continuous Compounding
* Effective Interest Rate and Force of Interest
* Present Value and Discount Rate
* Inflation and Real Rate of Interest

Chapter 2 : Basic Annuity Theory [Another Prerequisite]
* Basic definition of Annuity and the Valuation of Annuity
* Annuity Immediate, Annuity Due, Deferred Annuity, Perpetuity, Non-Level Annuity and Continuous Annuity
* Application of Annuity

Chapter 3 : Loan Repayment
* Basic Terminologies of Amortized Loan and some basic theories
* Special Topic about Loan: Refinancing, Loan Repayment Holiday, Floating Rate Loan etc
* Sinking Fund Method
* Loan with other repayment methods

Chapter 4 : Bonds
* Basic Terminologies of Bonds
* Bond Pricing Using Yield Rate
* Calculation of dirty price and clean price of a bond
* Bond Amortization Schedule
* Pricing of Callable Bonds

Chapter 5 : Measuring Rate of Return of an Investment
* NPV and IRR
* Dollar-Weighted Return and Time-Weighted Return

Chapter 6 : Term Structure of Interest Rate and Interest Rate Sensitivity
* Spot Rates and Forward Rates
* Macaulay Duration, Modified Duration, and Modified Convexity.

*Note 1: For this term, Continuous Annuity and the last part of Chapter 6 is not discussed due to time constraint.
*Note 2: Please note that if you are taking SOA Exam-FM, then you need to either study other materials on your own, or take MATH4511/MATH4514.
*Note 3: Additional materials for SOA Exam FM: BOND IMMUNIZATION and INTEREST RATE SWAPS. Refer to attachment for detail.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is very well. Don't worry too much about his language; it's understandable and his English is somewhat fluent.
His lecture notes are so tidy and detailed that people can understand what is actually written there. Despite so, I still recommend you to go to his lectures, since he explains materials quite clearly, so that you can understand materials better. One bad thing is that he always delays the lecture ending time, but usually that's the most crucial part of the whole lecture. :/
Another reason why you should go to his lectures is because he may set up a "difficult" midterm and final exams, in case few people attend his lecture (which actually happens for this term).

Assignment 2: 100 + 60 bonus marks

Assignment 4: 100 + 55 bonus marks

* Final : 65%

Assignment 2 : 89.26 + 36.85 bonus marks
Assignment 3 : 84.53 + 34.96 bonus marks
Assignment 4 : 91.51 + 36.60 bonus marks

*Note 1: The 4 assignments are graded by TA, while the midterm and final are graded by Dr. LCM
*Note 2: Bonus Marks are used to top-up your assignments, midterm, and final scores. Conversion: 8 bonus marks = 1 Midterm score ; 13 bonus marks = 1 Final score (if your midterm has achieved 100%)
*Note 3: There are 4 computational problems for Midterm, 8 computational problems + 1 MCQ (theoritical problem) + 1 Proof problem for Final
*Note 4: Since only ~30 people attended the lectures, some of the final exam questions are exclusively designed for those who actually attended the lectures. For example, the proof of Theorem 1 and Theorem 2 in Page 66 & 67 of Chapter 4 is asked directly.
*Note 5: For this term, it is actually quite hard to get A range (i.e. 80% or above), due to its "tedious" grading in exams. I saw people were so frustrated about the grading; I saw people get 0 marks in several questions, in which I think they deserve to get some points, but only because LCM thinks that it is a WRONG CONCEPT (curse u!!!)
*For my total score, I got full marks for all 4 assignments (with 215 bonus marks), 55 for my midterm, and 61 for my final. Hence, my final score is equal to: 15%*(100) + 20%*(55 + 215/8) + 65%*(61) = 71.05 (215/8 is rounded up to 27, and even though you get 209 for your bonus marks, it will still be rounded up to 27). That gives me a B+ (super sad, knowing that people getting 80% in total get an A)

reviews.author: kptss88
reviews.title: great FUNDAMENTAL financial math course with great lecturer
reviews.comment_content:
( you may see the attachment for basic information.)

Generally speaking, It is a greater course to introduce the FUNDAMENTAL math used in finance and insurance. Perhaps since I am a MATH major, I prefer to formulae and equations rather than words to understand the concept, and therefore, this course is much better than FINA2203/2303 for me, or somebody like me.
The reason why this course is great is its broadness and simplicity. It brings you into the different topics from shallow to deep : From the basic various concepts of "interest" for dealing with different type of series of cashflow (annuities) to their applications in loans, bonds and analysis of cashflows (NPV, IRR, dollar/time-weighted rate of return), and finally,  the course will introduce the concept of term structure of interest rate, forward rate, duration and convexity, which are the basic concepts in other financial topics like portfolio management, financial derivatives and risk hedging.
I think it is useful for MATH(SF-track) since you will take MATH4512 later (or now), which the materials in FINA2203 cannot sufficiently support you to understand Prof. K___'s "good" teaching as well as you can learn the similar thing in FINA2203 but in a more math way.
By the way, Please be noticed that it is also the pre-requisite of other important ACTM electives, like MATH 4427 (In the coming year, this will be divided into 2 courses) and MATH 4514. If you cannot handle with this course well, please re-decide whether you are suitable to the actuarial science since it is already a FUNDAMENTAL course.
By the way again, this course is designed for the SOA exam FM but some areas are not yet covered: Immunization, Interest Rate Swap, Determinants of Interest Rates. Except for the part of Immunisation, there are study notes on the website of SOA, so you may have to self-learn them if you want to take SOA exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Leung is a newcomer of MATH department yet with quite a lot teaching experience in other HK colleges. I adore him greatly in his teaching since he taught much better than other instructors that he explained the concept detailly with backup of many useful examples, which was, however, also his shortcoming that he used most of the time in the examples, then he did not have enough time to the materials in last few weeks.
Also, he is very nice to the students. he is welcome to chat with the students on different topics (simply in Cantonese, "吹水"), and kindheartedly to who seek him for help on the homework or the course.
Also, he focuses on teaching the ACTM courses, which means that if you take ACTM minor, you will possibly see him 3 times for MATH 2511 (core course), MATH 4427 and MATH 4514 (the most recommendable electives in ACTM).
By the way, I was surprised that he looks like a tutor rather than a lecturer in the first sight in the first class.
reviews.comment_grading:
5~6 Assignments -- 10%
Midterm -- 20%
    closed book with formula sheet provided
Final -- 70%
    accumulative and closed book with formula sheet provided

It is moderately a good grading course that getting about 80% overall you will have an A- as well as there is 30% of the A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is rather low that the assignments may possibly take you about a few hours, perhaps longer time for the bonus part. Interestingly, each assignment will have some bonus questions, which are optional, and students can get "bonus score" by completing some bonus questions for adding marks to the assignments, midterm and final.
     ==> All people will do all of them for the bonus score, and I have heard that someone did get 10 bonus points (max. in my semester) resulting in one higher subgrade.

Although the compulsory part of the assignment is the easy step-by-step calculation helping you familiar with the formulae and equations, the bonus part is quite tricky and consists of the proof-type problems. Also, you must be clear of the concepts and cautious of the calculation since the midterm and the final are somehow difficult.

reviews.comment_content:
Basic knowledge in differentiation and integration is required.

1. Basic Interest Theory: simple interest, compound interest, continuous compounding, force of interest, effective interest rate, simple discount, compound discount, present value, inflation, real rate of interest
2. Basic Annuity Theory: annuity-immediate, annuity-due, perpetuity, deferred annuity, continuous annuity, level annuity, non-level annuity
3. Loan Repayment: outstanding balance, interest due, principal repaid, balloon payment and drop payment, prime rate, refinancing, loan repayment holiday, sinking fund method
4. Bonds: pricing formula, premium-discount formula, dirty price and clean price, book value, callable bond, the "loan repayment" perspective of bonds, Newton's method
5. Measuring the Rate of Return of an Investment: Net Present Value, Internal Rate of Return, Time-Weighted Rate of Return, Dollar-Weighted Rate of Return
6. Term Structures of Interest Rate and Interest Rate Sensitivity: spot rate, forward rate, Macaulay duration, Modified duration, first-order and second-order approximations (application of Taylor series), interest rate risk, bond immunization

reviews.author: PimpDaddy
reviews.comment_content: This course prepares students to take the SOA F/M examination. It is also suited to students who wish to understand the mathematics underlying loans, bonds, and some simpler stocks. The knowledge is entirely cumulative, with knowledge previously learned in the course essential to understanding the later parts. The knowledge itself is simple, the proofs are straightforward with only elementary mathematics necessary, and the applications are plentiful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Huang is without a doubt an extremely hard-working instructor. He teaches very clearly and explains all the proofs and origins of equations. Sometimes this is excessive but it is worth listening during the lecture because he always delivers financial intuition associated with equations.
Dr. Huang also uploads every single video of his lectures as well as the class script that is projected to the screen of diagrams. He responds to feedback regarding his teaching very well because he strives to ensure all students learn well.
reviews.comment_grading: Dr. Huang explicitly states that he will ensure that students get the highest possible grade from the ARRO, so grading is not an issue. On the other hand, 65% of the grade comes from the final exam; the rest comes from the midterm. Therefore every question answered is quite important in terms of the total grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are only 4 assignments with 1 additional optional assignment. You will have around 1-2 weeks to complete it. Generally, the questions come from the course textbook.
The answers are given quickly with worked solutions by the TA. The assignments are always related to the concepts learned very recently during the lectures.
In other words, the workload is quite low.

reviews.author: ylh
reviews.title: Nice professor, but not really a useful course
reviews.comment_content:
Introductory course to financial mathematics. Teaches about the present value concept and its calculation. The concept is similar to those finance courses, but teaches in a more mathematical way. It will be an advantage if you have studied FINA2203/2303.

However, I personally do not think the content is useful. and rewarding. The course requires a lot of tedious computational work and it is easy to make some errors. The process is completely unnecessary. For instance, you can use financial calculator to find IRR instead of using Newton's Method to solve for the equation; or plug in formulas in Excel to find out the outstanding balance during the loan repayment period.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Nice and friendly professor. His teaching is very clear and not boring. Although the class size is quite big, he still managed to recognise all the faces in the classroom. I skipped all lessons after midterm and he knows :0

The materials are well-prepared and understandable. Textbooks are not needed.

However, NEVER challenge his grading scheme or you will die!!!
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Assignment
20% Midterm
65% Final

Good grading.
The course uses absolute grading scheme, but the professor will adjust the curve due to the poor performance in exams (mean:~47). Also, there are bonus scores from assignments to top-up your midterm/final exam score. 8 bonus score equals to 1 midterm score. I personally got 81% in this course. According to the grading scheme, I would get B+, but the professor tries to give the best possible grade to students, so I eventually got A.

The exam is tedious though. Many computational work is needed, and it includes proof/multiple choice questions. Besides, LCM emphasises on how you present your answer. Sometimes you cannot earn full credit even you think you have explained everything well. So it is better to follow every step in the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_workload:
Adequate. 4 assignments in total, and the difficulty is similar to the exams. Each assignment will take you 4-5 hours to finish it.

If you have studied FINA2203/2303, the concept would be clear. However, you still have to practice for the computation.

reviews.comment_grading:
There are five assignments worth 10% (2% each). There is a midterm worth 20%, and a final worth 70%. It is said that
The course has absolute grading: 60% B range, 85% A range. Depending on how other people did, the professor can be lenient about this and can lower the grade boundaries.
During each assignment, there are bonus question. These bonus questions can be used to increase assignment, midterm, and final score. The final exam is mostly the deciding factor of the course. However, if you get almost full marks on the assignment, the bonus marks can help you increase your final grade by a sub grade. The midterm and final exams are basically like a math exam. You are given limited amount of time and a lot of questions. It is impossible to solve all questions in the exams. Marking is very nice and you are able to gain a lot of points by just writing down how you will approach the question.
reviews.comment_workload: The assignments are time consuming even if each assignment is only worth 2 percent. However, as I said, getting full marks on assignments and bonus scores can boost up your final grade by a sub grade. The exam prep does not take too long. Just review the assignment questions (especially the bonus questions) and solve the problem sets given.

reviews.comment_content: You can learn some basic ideas in the financial area if you are a science student. Since I have never studied FINA before, it's totally a good course for me to bridge me into financial courses.
reviews.comment_teaching:
LCM is a pretty friendly and nice professor. His teaching is very clear. (somehow please try to understand his English at the beginning of the class)

The materials are well-prepared and understandable. Textbooks are not needed. There are six chapters in the lecture notes, and, due to the time constraint, he covered basic interest theory, annuity theory, loan repayments, bonds, measuring rate of returns, and the term structure of interest rate.

Sometimes, the tutorial will be the class time if needed, and, in the normal tutorials, the TA will pass the worksheet for us to practice. (It will be also uploaded to the Canvas)
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Assignment
20% Midterm
65% Final

Good grading!
It's an absolute grading class, and it's not too hard for you to get high marks if you tried your best to finish the assignment (you'll get bonus points to top-up your midterm and final grades.)

To correct the previous review, it would be 9 bonus score equals to 1 midterm score and 15 bonus score equals to 1 final score. I got A+ in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Depends on you. You can spend 3 hours a week like me to finish all the problem sets, but you can also do nothing but attend the class. (or even not attend, the lecture notes are clear)

There are 4 assignments this semester and the difficulty is slightly easier to the exams. Each assignment will take you at least 3 hours to finish it.

A crucial tip to get a good grade is to practice again and again for the computation.

reviews.comment_grading:
The bonus scheme is good in this course to give hardworking students upgrade their grades. However, the professor's marking style in midterms and final exams are quite harsh. Even you have listed out all the steps which you thought are clear, if he could not understand what you wrote, he would deducted you at least half of your marks. Also, the homework was graded by TA, so you will never know whether your answers can get adequate scores in exams. Even you get all answers correct with correct steps you thought were "clear", you could still get 3 out of 10 marks.  Moreover, he said he used absolute grading, however, his exams are usually tedious and difficult with low mean. So, I don't think his courses' grading are great and do not understand why people say his courses have "good grades". I personally get a "C" from his course. Even your total final score after adding bonus is above 70 (mean is around 54 in total) , you only get B+. Extremely difficult to get A range.
Therefore, if you want to get A range in his course, you should write solutions fulfilling "his marking schemes" which he thinks is "clear".
